metadata.h1: Logistic Regression without technical jargon + comparison to tree models
metadata.description: 1) What is Logistic Regression and what so good about it 2) Understand the difference between this algorithm and Random Forest, and which one is better to use by using a pepperoni pizza 3) Updates from my side

all_paragraphs: Logistic regression is very commonly used for telling us if an event is T or F, for example, will this customer stay or leave, is this email spam or non-spam, will someone get this disease or not, etc. I saw a couple of times that people claim this is THE most commonly used algorithm. So let’s talk about it.

Suppose we have 1000 new customers as warm leads in our funnel. We know that some customers are more likely to stay with us than others. In other words, some customers fit our profile better or require less energy from us to close the deal. We want to identify who they are.

And since this is a mutually exclusive event, the more likely that a customer will stay with us, the less likely a customer will leave us. So let’s state our goal here: we want a model, such that if Customer A is likely to stay with us, it will tell us the probability for the event “stay” is very high or the probability of “not stay” (1-stay) is low and vice versa. (Remember this, we will come back to this later!)

We have three variables, they are the size of the contracts ($ value), the type of the customers (B2C vs. B2C), and the channels of how they got to know us. It is very intuitive for us to start thinking that we need to look at our previous customers and see what’s the relationship between these three variables and the outcome. This is the right direction except we have a problem here.

In the traditional linear equation which we learned back in middle school or high school, it doesn’t represent probability; it gives us a definite answer. To show you what I mean, in Image 3 equation 1) we can use some previous data and have a function that calculates the percentage of “stay” for A, or B, or C … and we will need another function to calculate the percentage of “not stay” for A, or B, or C. These two percentages will not necessarily add up to 1 because they do not represent probabilities.

Therefore, some smart guys start thinking, what if, I upgrade the Y so that it directly produces an outcome that compares the probability of the event “stay” and the probability of the event “not stay”, in other words, it tells me which event is likely to happen than the other (Image 4). And that’s how we go from function 1) to function 2)! Function 2) directly gives us the ratio of the probability of “stay” and the probability of “not stay”

The reason is very simple. It is because when we are comparing how much time A is more than B, the number can range from 0 to infinity. Think about it, you are 100, 1000, 10000… times more awesome than the person you don’t like. There is NO LIMIT to how big the “times” can be (of course!). On the other hand, if we want to express less likely, we don’t have a way to do it because the minimum of the numerator of our equation 2), the probability of event A is 0. There is no negative probability.

To solve this problem, we move from equation 2) to equation 3) by logging the Y. If you need some reminders on how a logarithm works, I attached an image of a logarithm scale based on 10 vs. a linear scale below. Simply put, it is just a different way to measure things, like feet to cm. Now we are ready to use our data and solve those coefficients!

I believe not many people back in school liked the homework of solving those coefficients. So that’s why we want to use an algorithm!! There is nothing fancy. In the context of logistic regression, after you input your data, your computer tells you the coefficients, rather than a magic answer.
Our computer will get the best coefficients for us by trying a bunch of different lines! How do we define the best one? Remember what’s our goal?

we want a model, such that if Customer A is very likely to stay with us, it will tell us the probability for the event “stay” is very high or the probability of “not stay” (1-stay) is low and vice versa.
Thus, the definition of best coefficients is the ones that enable the most amount of cases to satisfy our defined goal.

So now, the computer has given us the coefficients. We have solved the relationship between the three variables and the outcome! Now we want to get insights from our function. However, remember we changed our Y, so it is a bit tricky to interpret. Let’s give make up some accurate numbers to walk through the process.

The first coefficient means that 1 unit of increase in x1 (everything else doesn’t change), will increase the ratio of probability x to probability (1-x) by 0.005 on a logarithm scale; on the other hand,1 unit of increase of x2, will decrease the ratio by 0.65 on a logarithm scale.

Since in life, we use a linear scale instead of a logarithm scale, we can convert it back to a linear scale using e. In the example of x2, before, the likelihood of event “stay” will happen is 1.17 times more likely than the event “not stay”. However, after 1 unit of change in x2, though “stay” is still more likely to occur, the ratio decreased to only 0.52 times more likely now.

Not only that you know who is likely to stay and where you should put your energy, but among those who are likely to stay, you even know who’s the most likely to stay! So now, you can rank your customers or have different expected timelines for different customers!!

For example, for less-likely customers, reserve more time because it’s gonna be a long battle, and don’t feel bad about yourself if you didn’t get it at the first attempt :) And for those who have are a lot more likely to be “not stay” then stay, we don’t even need to bother now!!
There are many angles we can (and probably should) use to address this question, but I only want to give the most intuitive answer here.

Imagine your roommate asks you to divide the pizza evenly into 2 and because you like pepperoni, you are thinking about how you can cut it so that you can maximize the pepperoni you get. In Logistic regression, you can only pick a line to cut, though you still have many options, whereas, in a decision tree, there’s no such rule.

The reason for this difference is that in a tree model, we use a set of logical statements (Yes or No questions) to draw our conclusions whereas, for logistical regression, we define a set of numeric relationships. When we are using a set of numbers to express a relationship, we have already pre-determined an equation, a pre-determined structure to express the relation. For example, we have equation 1), 2), and 3), and we only want to find the coefficients. When we are using a set of logical statements, we don’t specify what kinds of structure the relationship will be like.

Keep in mind that “if a model is good?” or “which model should be used?” can expand into a huge topic of model evaluation, something I plan to write a separate blog. It is crucial for everyone to understand how we should or can evaluate a model because many times, which model to use in production is not just decided by people with a solid tech background. For now, let’s just discuss the basics.

Continuing with the pizza analogy, the first method is to count which one gives us the most pepperonis. However, most of the times things are not so clear. If you look at the pizza carefully, by using the logistical regression divide, we can get 7–7.5 pepperonis, and the tree model gives us 8 pepperonis. There’s not an obvious difference. Taking into account that the pepperonis’ positions are slightly different for every pizza, a logistical regression might outperform the tree model sometimes. That’s why you see a data scientist uses 2 or 3 models sometimes and see which one does the best job.

Another approach to thinking about this, is to ask: other than the model accuracy, what kind of information will help you to address your business problem the most? Like I mentioned in my previous article, the best part of a tree model (including random forest) is that it tells you which logical statement matters the most. In our pizza example, if each rectangle is a logical statement, it would be the one on the most left because gives us three pepperonis. For a logistical regression, the best part is that it not only gives us pepperonis, but it also tells us which pepperoni is the biggest and ranks it for us.

Therefore, in the context of business, if I am developing a product and want to improve features, tree model will help us to determine which feature is most important to improve because that feature will bring us most customers, but if I want to close as many contracts as possible by the end of the month, a logistical regression will tell us which customers to target first because they are most likely to stay with us to start with.

From Monday to Tuesday, after I posted my previous article on Monday night, I experienced almost a panic attack because I realized some mistakes that I made in the article (fixed already).
